H0.text: Algae are the group of organisms most responsible for changing the composition of Earth's early atmosphere.

H1.text: Fungi are the group of organisms most responsible for changing the composition of Earth's early atmosphere.

H2.text: Reptiles are the group of organisms most responsible for changing the composition of Earth's early atmosphere.

H3.text: Angiosperms are the group of organisms most responsible for changing the composition of Earth's early atmosphere.

A4.text: The rise in oxygen is attributed to photosynthesis by cyanobacteria, which are thought to have evolved as early as 3.5 billion years ago.

A5.text: The Great Oxidation Event was caused by cyanobacteria, which evolved chlorophyll-based photosynthesis that releases dioxygen as a byproduct of water photolysis.

A6.text: The large amounts of oxygen in the atmosphere are considered to have been first created by the activities of ancient cyanobacteria.

A7.text: Oxygenic photosynthesis only evolved once (in prokaryotic cyanobacteria), and all photosynthetic eukaryotes (including all plants and algae) have acquired this ability from endosymbiosis with cyanobacteria or their endosymbiont hosts.

A8.text: Cyanobacteria remained the principal primary producers of oxygen throughout the Proterozoic Eon, in part because the redox structure of the oceans favored photoautotrophs capable of nitrogen fixation.

A9.text: The biochemical capacity to use water as the source for electrons in photosynthesis evolved once, in a common ancestor of extant cyanobacteria.
